review.title: Identity and Granularity of Events in Text
review.abstract: In this paper we describe a method to detect event descrip- tions in different news articles and to model the semantics of events and their components using RDF representations. We compare these descriptions to solve a cross-document event coreference task. Our com- ponent approach to event semantics defines identity and granularity of events at different levels. It performs close to state-of-the-art approaches on the cross-document event coreference task, while outperforming other works when assuming similar quality of event detection. We demonstrate how granularity and identity are interconnected and we discuss how se- mantic anomaly could be used to define differences between coreference, subevent and topical relations.

sections.heading: 2 Related work
sections.text: After the initial focus on entity co-referencing, there has recently been a growing interest in the field of event co-referencing resolution. Some monitored approaches to event co-referencing resolution have been proposed by Humphreys et al. [19], Bagga and Baldwin [3], Ahn [1] or Chen and Ji [11]. These methods are based on supervised learning of rich linguistic features to determine co-references in a paired model and are highly domain dependent. This is not the case for the method presented in Section 7, which is not supervised. Furthermore, this work depends on local decisions, without taking into account global event distribution at the document level. The bag event model implemented here enables us to overcome this deficit.

sections.heading: 4 Modelling event coreference: bag of events approach
sections.text: It is quite common practice to use information derived from event arguments for event corrections ([19], [10], [5], [12], [24] among others), but the use of entities for event corrections is complicated by the fact that event descriptions within a sentence often lack information. It may be the case that a missing piece of information is available elsewhere within discourse boundaries, which is a challenge for paired events with others at the sentence level. To be able to use information coming from event controls rather than seeking information available within discourse boundaries is a challenge for paired mentions.

sections.heading: 5.1 One- vs. two-step classification
sections.text: The peculiarity of the implementation of the two-step approach is that the two-step approach begins with the completion of a document template and the mentions of the five document templates are strung together: actions, places, times, persons contained in a document. In a document, no distinction is made between the individual components of a document and no information is given about the individual components of a document. A document can be regarded as a bag of events and events.

sections.heading: 5.2 Experiment set-up
sections.text: For correlation experiments on real mentions, we used a subset of ECB + annotations (based on a list of 1840 selected sentences, [14]), which were additionally reviewed with an emphasis on correlation. We divided the corpus into a training set (topics 1-35) and a test set (topics 36-45). ECB + texts are available in XML format. Texts are tokenized, so there was no need for sentence segmentation or tokenization. We staggered (for the purpose of proper verb lemmatization) and lemmatized the corpus sentences. We used tools from the Natural Language Toolkit ([6], NLTK version 2.0.4): the standard POS tagger, Word-Net lemmatizer1, and the WordNet synset assignment by NLTK2.

sections.heading: 6 Door-to-door implementation
sections.text: In previous sections 4 and 5, true mentions were used to evaluate the approach. In this section, we describe how to extract event data from the raw text (system mentions) and then establish an interdocumentary event correlation in a two-step approach. To extract event data from the text, we use the NLP pipeline developed in the NewsReader project. 3 NewsReader applies a cascade of semantic modules, among which: named entity recognition and classification (NERC), namedentity linking (NEL), semantic role labeling (SRL), time print recognition and normalization, time anchoring, event and entity coreference. The same entity, event or time expression can be mentioned several times in a document. The above modules interpret each occurrence separately and annotate the tokens accordingly.

sections.heading: 7 Experiments with coreference on system mentions
sections.text: We evaluate the NewsReader system on the same ECB + dataset. We compare the NewsReader results with Yang et al. (2015) [34], who mentioned the best results for Event Coreference Resolution System for ECB + and who also compare their results with other systems that have so far only been tested on ECB and not on ECB +. Yang et al use a distance-dependent Chinese restaurant process (DDCRP [8]), which is an infinite clustering model that can take into account data dependencies. They define a hierarchical variant (HDDCRP) in which they first use event mentions and data within a document and the next cluster within the document cluster across documents. Their hierarchical strategy is similar to our approach with event components, in the sense that event data can be streamed across multiple sets in a document and must be collected first.

sections.heading: 9 Conclusion
sections.text: The proposed heuristics exceed the state-of-the-art system if they provide the same quality of event detection. Our approach collects component information from the complete document, rather than from the local context of the event mentions compared. We have shown that event components play a role in achieving precision and retrieval, and that their adaptation needs to be adapted to the granularity of the task. In future work, we intend to examine the event correlation in terms of topical structures and lines of action.
